facts.text: Balmokand Radheshyam, a firm with head office at Calcutta, carried on business in commission agency and cotton piece-goods, consisting of four partners including Shivram Poddar, the appellant.
The firm was dissolved in February 1950, and its business was discontinued.
For the assessment year 1949-50, one of the partners submitted a return of the firm's income, and it was assessed on October 28, 1952, in the status of an unregistered firm.

On March 28, 1955, the Income-tax Officer issued a notice under section 34 read with section 22(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, to the appellant as a partner of the firm at the time of its dissolution, calling upon him to submit a return of the income of the firm for the year ending March 31, 1950.

The appellant moved the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta for a writ of mandamus under Article 226 of the Constitution commanding the Income-tax Officer to forbear from giving effect to the notice.
The writ petition was dismissed by D.N. Sinha J., and that order was confirmed in appeal under the Letters Patent by the High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the income earned by the firm in the year ending March 1950 could be assessed to tax under section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, after the firm was dissolved.

petitioner_arguments.text: The notice addressed by the Income-tax Officer to the appellant was in law inoperative, since section 44 applies in relation to a firm only when there is discontinuance of its business and not when there is dissolution of the firm.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; observations in R.N. Bose v. Manindra Lal Goswami

petitioner_arguments.text: Dissolution and discontinuance are different concepts; if discontinuance included dissolution it was unnecessary to make express provision for dissolution of association of persons.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

court_reasoning.text: Section 44 authorises assessment of tax on income earned before discontinuance or dissolution and imposes joint and several liability on partners at the time of discontinuance or dissolution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The object is to ensure continuity in assessment machinery notwithstanding discontinuance.

court_reasoning.text: In C.A. Abraham v. Income-tax Officer, the Court observed that assessment proceedings may be commenced and continued against a firm after discontinuance as if it had not taken place.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applies even after dissolution upon death of partner.

court_reasoning.text: Section 44 operates on discontinuance of business by firm or association, or dissolution of association; for firms, it applies on discontinuance whether resulting from dissolution or other cause.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere dissolution without discontinuance does not attract s.44 for firms.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction due to scheme of Income-tax Act treating firm as unit of assessment independent of partners; reconstitution does not discontinue business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions like ss.25(1), 26(1),(2) handle changes in constitution or succession.

court_reasoning.text: In this case, business was discontinued on dissolution, so s.44 applies; firm remains liable as unregistered firm.
High Court writ jurisdiction under Art.226 not for bypassing revenue machinery unless fundamental rights infringed or lack of jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Revenue to ascertain facts and grant relief.

holdings.text: Section 44 is attracted only when the business of a firm is discontinued, i.e., complete cessation, whether as a result of dissolution or other cause.
A dissolved firm which has discontinued business is assessed under the Act's machinery, with partners jointly and severally liable.

precedents_cited.case_name: C.A. Abraham v. Income-tax Officer, Kottayam
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessment and penalty proceedings valid after discontinuance due to dissolution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Raja Reddy Mallaram
precedents_cited.relevance: Reiterated application of s.44 to dissolved association of persons.

precedents_cited.case_name: R.N. Bose v. Manindra Lal Goswami
precedents_cited.relevance: Obiter observations that s.44 does not expressly cover dissolution of firm, but parties proceeded on assumption it did.
Section 25(1) enables premature assessment on discontinuance.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs assessment of discontinued or dissolved firms/associations; joint liability on partners; machinery for assessment despite changes.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction for mandamus against ITO notice.

outcome.summary: The appeal against the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition is dismissed. The notice under s.34 r/w s.22(2) is valid as s.44 applies to assessment of the firm's income after discontinuance of business upon dissolution, with partners jointly liable.

key_quotes.text: "In effect, the Legislature has enacted by section 44 that the assessment proceedings may be commenced and continued against a firm of which business is discontinued as if discontinuance has not taken place."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose of s.44 for continuity of assessment.

key_quotes.text: "Section 44 is, therefore, attracted only when the business of a firm is discontinued, i.e., when there is complete cessation of the business and not when there is a change in the ownership of the firm, or in its constitution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of s.44 for firms distinct from AOP.

key_quotes.text: "Resort to the High Court in exercise of its extraordinary jurisdiction conferred on recognised by the Constitution in matters relating to assessment, levy and collection of income-tax may be permitted only when questions of infringement of fundamental rights arise."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits writ jurisdiction in tax matters.
